issue.title: Put `ArrayBuffer::external()` behind a flag
issue.body:
External ArrayBuffers are effectively becoming an optional feature of Node-API because of new features in V8 that are incompatible with external buffers, especially now that [Electron will be enabling these features by default](https://www.electronjs.org/blog/v8-memory-cage).

We will need to put `ArrayBuffer::external()` behind a flag and disable it by default, with documentation that explains what happens if you try to use the API in an environment that disables it (such as recent versions of Electron). My understanding is that it immediately but cleanly terminates the Node process.

pull_request.title: `TypedArray::from_slice()`
pull_request.body:
This PR follows on #909 with an additional `TypedArray::from_slice()` method, making it convenient and easy to copy from a Rust slice into a new typed array.

This is not only convenient, but also mitigates the ergonomic cost of deprecating `JsArrayBuffer::external()`, which seems like it'll be necessary due to recent changes in V8 to deprecate external typed arrays.

pull_request.title: Speed-Up CI
pull_request.body:
This makes a few changes to our CI process to make it run faster.

* Adds caching of artifacts (Rust, NPM, Electron)
* Collapses to a single CI file for tests to minimize duplication
* Only run on Node LTS and Rust Stable in PRs
  - Runs the full matrix if the "full matrix" label is provided
  - Runs the full matrix on Linux
* Runs the full matrix when *merged*

Try changing the labels on the PR to test it out!

**Note**: Matrix includes do not include arrays for a 2nd pass of expansion; instead they become literal arrays. As a workaround, I included a JavaScript snippet in the setup step that performs a manual expansion of the matrix.

pull_request.title: Typed Array discoverability
pull_request.body:
This PR adds API docs for typed arrays, as well as several conveniences in the API:

- `JsTypedArray::new()` and `JsTypedArray::from_buffer` for constructing typed array objects
- Type aliases for typed array types (e.g. `JsUint32Array`)

Collectively, these changes should **make the Neon typed arrays API more discoverable** and easier to get started using.

RFC: neon-bindings/rfcs#47

comment.body:
Since these bounds are only required for the `PhantomData<T>` field of `JsTypedArrayInner`, I can reduce the requirements from `Debug + Copy` to just `Clone` by manually implementing `Debug`.

I'm a little reluctant to remove the `Clone` super type constraint and propagate it into the declarations, since it pollutes all the impl declarations everywhere. This means a bunch of methods just disappear when your `Binary` type happens not to be `Clone`, which just seems like `JsTypedArray` just doesn't really work as expected unless your `Binary` type is also `Clone`. I feel like I'd rather just express that it's a requirement of the trait.

It is an annoying requirement of the Rust compiler, though. It's frustrating that you can't declare `impl<T: Binary> Copy for JsTypedArrayInner<T> {}` if `T` isn't `Clone`, even though it's only used as a phantom type. (I wonder if that's what [this issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/50980) is about?)

But in the end it seems pretty reasonable to require a `Binary` type to be `Clone`, since binary data is just sequences of bits. What do you think of leaving it at `trait Binary: Sealed + Clone`?

comment.body:
I'm open to anything, and a `RangeError` is certainly consistent with what the JS constructors do (e.g. `new Uint32Array(new ArrayBuffer(7))` throws a `RangeError`). I think an error other than `JsResult` would make the API too painful, so that leaves either panicking or throwing a `RangeError`.

I guess my only question is whether it's weird to throw a JavaScript exception from something that seems more like a pure Rust operation. But I think since it's trying to allocate a new JS object, it's reasonable for that to throw a JS exception. So why don't we go with throwing a `RangeError`.

issue.title: Put `ArrayBuffer::external()` behind a flag
issue.body:
External ArrayBuffers are effectively becoming an optional feature of Node-API because of new features in V8 that are incompatible with external buffers, especially now that [Electron will be enabling these features by default](https://www.electronjs.org/blog/v8-memory-cage).

We will need to put `ArrayBuffer::external()` behind a flag and disable it by default, with documentation that explains what happens if you try to use the API in an environment that disables it (such as recent versions of Electron). My understanding is that it immediately but cleanly terminates the Node process.

pull_request.title: Speed-Up CI
pull_request.body:
This makes a few changes to our CI process to make it run faster.

* Adds caching of artifacts (Rust, NPM, Electron)
* Collapses to a single CI file for tests to minimize duplication
* Only run on Node LTS and Rust Stable in PRs
  - Runs the full matrix if the "full matrix" label is provided
  - Runs the full matrix on Linux
* Runs the full matrix when *merged*

Try changing the labels on the PR to test it out!

**Note**: Matrix includes do not include arrays for a 2nd pass of expansion; instead they become literal arrays. As a workaround, I included a JavaScript snippet in the setup step that performs a manual expansion of the matrix.

comment.body:
Since these bounds are only required for the `PhantomData<T>` field of `JsTypedArrayInner`, I can reduce the requirements from `Debug + Copy` to just `Clone` by manually implementing `Debug`.

I'm a little reluctant to remove the `Clone` super type constraint and propagate it into the declarations, since it pollutes all the impl declarations everywhere. This means a bunch of methods just disappear when your `Binary` type happens not to be `Clone`, which just seems like `JsTypedArray` just doesn't really work as expected unless your `Binary` type is also `Clone`. I feel like I'd rather just express that it's a requirement of the trait.

It is an annoying requirement of the Rust compiler, though. It's frustrating that you can't declare `impl<T: Binary> Copy for JsTypedArrayInner<T> {}` if `T` isn't `Clone`, even though it's only used as a phantom type. (I wonder if that's what [this issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/50980) is about?)

But in the end it seems pretty reasonable to require a `Binary` type to be `Clone`, since binary data is just sequences of bits. What do you think of leaving it at `trait Binary: Sealed + Clone`?

comment.body:
I'm open to anything, and a `RangeError` is certainly consistent with what the JS constructors do (e.g. `new Uint32Array(new ArrayBuffer(7))` throws a `RangeError`). I think an error other than `JsResult` would make the API too painful, so that leaves either panicking or throwing a `RangeError`.

I guess my only question is whether it's weird to throw a JavaScript exception from something that seems more like a pure Rust operation. But I think since it's trying to allocate a new JS object, it's reasonable for that to throw a JS exception. So why don't we go with throwing a `RangeError`.

- Type aliases for typed array types (e.g. `JsUint32Array`)

Collectively, these changes should **make the Neon typed arrays API more discoverable** and easier to get started using.

RFC: neon-bindings/rfcs#47

issue.title: Put `ArrayBuffer::external()` behind a flag
issue.body:
External ArrayBuffers are effectively becoming an optional feature of Node-API because of new features in V8 that are incompatible with external buffers, especially now that [Electron will be enabling these features by default](https://www.electronjs.org/blog/v8-memory-cage).

We will need to put `ArrayBuffer::external()` behind a flag and disable it by default, with documentation that explains what happens if you try to use the API in an environment that disables it (such as recent versions of Electron). My understanding is that it immediately but cleanly terminates the Node process.

pull_request.title: Speed-Up CI
pull_request.body:
This makes a few changes to our CI process to make it run faster.

* Adds caching of artifacts (Rust, NPM, Electron)
* Collapses to a single CI file for tests to minimize duplication
* Only run on Node LTS and Rust Stable in PRs
  - Runs the full matrix if the "full matrix" label is provided
  - Runs the full matrix on Linux
* Runs the full matrix when *merged*

Try changing the labels on the PR to test it out!

**Note**: Matrix includes do not include arrays for a 2nd pass of expansion; instead they become literal arrays. As a workaround, I included a JavaScript snippet in the setup step that performs a manual expansion of the matrix.

comment.body:
Since these bounds are only required for the `PhantomData<T>` field of `JsTypedArrayInner`, I can reduce the requirements from `Debug + Copy` to just `Clone` by manually implementing `Debug`.

I'm a little reluctant to remove the `Clone` super type constraint and propagate it into the declarations, since it pollutes all the impl declarations everywhere. This means a bunch of methods just disappear when your `Binary` type happens not to be `Clone`, which just seems like `JsTypedArray` just doesn't really work as expected unless your `Binary` type is also `Clone`. I feel like I'd rather just express that it's a requirement of the trait.

It is an annoying requirement of the Rust compiler, though. It's frustrating that you can't declare `impl<T: Binary> Copy for JsTypedArrayInner<T> {}` if `T` isn't `Clone`, even though it's only used as a phantom type. (I wonder if that's what [this issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/50980) is about?)

But in the end it seems pretty reasonable to require a `Binary` type to be `Clone`, since binary data is just sequences of bits. What do you think of leaving it at `trait Binary: Sealed + Clone`?

pull_request.title: Typed Array discoverability
pull_request.body:
This PR adds API docs for typed arrays, as well as several conveniences in the API:

- `JsTypedArray::new()` and `JsTypedArray::from_buffer` for constructing typed array objects
- Type aliases for typed array types (e.g. `JsUint32Array`)

Collectively, these changes should **make the Neon typed arrays API more discoverable** and easier to get started using.

RFC: neon-bindings/rfcs#47

comment.body:
I'm open to anything, and a `RangeError` is certainly consistent with what the JS constructors do (e.g. `new Uint32Array(new ArrayBuffer(7))` throws a `RangeError`). I think an error other than `JsResult` would make the API too painful, so that leaves either panicking or throwing a `RangeError`.

I guess my only question is whether it's weird to throw a JavaScript exception from something that seems more like a pure Rust operation. But I think since it's trying to allocate a new JS object, it's reasonable for that to throw a JS exception. So why don't we go with throwing a `RangeError`.

review.body:
LGTM.

Eventually we'll want to have a docs page to help people deal with what will still likely be a common pitfall, when other parts of their build or packaging process happens to edit some .node file in-place. We can't protect against whatever they might do in their custom builds, so we'll probably end up needing some sort of troubleshooting guide.
